newsitem.title: INDIA: India meeting endorses international landmine ban.
newsitem.headline: India meeting endorses international landmine ban.

text.p: Military and humanitarian experts from several countries on Wednesday endorsed a world ban on landmines and condemned the deaths and maiming caused among civilians by thousands of the devices each year.

"Firstly, they do not discriminate the target and secondly, they continue to remain active long after the conflict has finished," said Major-General Dipankar Banerjee, director of the Institute for Peace and Conflict Studies.
Speakers at a meeting in the Indian capital noted that under the 1949 Geneva Convention all mines must be marked, recorded and removed after an armed conflict has ended.
The experts who endorsed an international ban were from India, Hong Kong, Ireland, Belgium, Norway, Canada and the International Committee of the Red Cross.
Banerjee said both sides in the three wars that India and Pakistan have fought since independence in 1947 had observed these rules.
He added that while the Convention has been followed by regular forces in conflicts across the world, the problem lay in the use of mines by guerrilla groups.
"In Kashmir," he said, "far more Indian soldiers and civilians have been maimed and killed than terrorists."
India and Pakistan have fought two of three wars over the disputed Himalayan territory of Kashmir.
A landmine explosion on Tuesday killed three Indian soldiers in Kashmir, and on Monday another blast killed two civilians and injured a police official.
International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) figures show that there are more than 119 million landmines scattered across 71 countries, with Afghanistan, Angola and Cambodia worst affected.
A spokesman from the ICRC estimated that landmines accounted for 24,000 casualties a year, a figure that translated to a death or maiming every 20 minutes.
An impressive list of states now back a total ban on landmine production and the movement to outlaw these weapons has gained considerable momentum over the past 12 months.

Last October, 50 states met in Ottawa and pledged to work together for a global ban on landmines and to increase resources available for mine clearance and assistance to victims who have lost limbs and livelihoods as a result.
In December 1996, 155 countries supported a United Nations General Assembly Resolution calling for a treaty to outlaw these weapons.
An international treaty banning the use of landmines is expected to be signed in Ottawa this December.
A total of 95 countries signed the so-called Brussels Declaration last June forming the basis for negotiations in Oslo, Norway in September on the exact wording of the Ottawa treaty.

An ICRC representative said that while the Ottawa meeting was an encouraging sign, there was an urgent need to increase funding for mine-clearing projects. "Banning them is one thing, removing them is the next task" he said.
